headline: Contributing to Web Development Documentation and core engine: My Journey with MDN and web.dev
description: Iurii Shapkarin contributions to major web development documentation platforms, including Mozilla's MDN (+it's engine) and Google's web.dev, highlighting the impact of small contributions in the open-source community.
keywords: open source contribution, gitHub, mozilla, mdn, google, web.dev, pull request, issues, javascript, web development, yari, mdn content, tab-glutton, open source, developer portfolio, community contribution

mainEntity.name: Why is contributing to open source important?

acceptedAnswer.text: Contributing to open source helps improve the tools and platforms developers use every day. It's also a great way to build skills, gain experience, collaborate with others, and create a strong portfolio that showcases your abilities to potential employers.

mainEntity.name: Do I need to be an expert to contribute?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, you don't need to be an expert. As the article shows, even small contributions matter. You can start by fixing typos in documentation, reporting issues, or working on beginner-friendly bugs. Every contribution, no matter how small, is valuable.

mainEntity.name: How can I find projects to contribute to?

acceptedAnswer.text: You can start with the tools you use daily. Check their GitHub repositories for a `CONTRIBUTING.md` file and look for issues labeled 'good first issue' or 'help wanted'. Websites like GitHub Explore and Up For Grabs also list projects seeking contributors.

name: How to Make Your First Open Source Contribution
description: A simple guide to making your first contribution to an open-source project on GitHub.

step.name: Find a Project
step.text: Choose a project you are interested in or use regularly. Explore its GitHub repository.

step.name: Find an Issue
step.text: Look for a good first issue to tackle. This could be a documentation update, a small bug fix, or a feature enhancement labeled for beginners.

step.name: Fork and Clone the Repository
step.text: Fork the project's repository to your own GitHub account and then clone it to your local machine.

step.name: Create a New Branch
step.text: Create a new branch for your changes. This keeps your work separate from the main codebase.

step.name: Make Your Changes
step.text: Implement your changes, whether it's code or documentation. Make sure to follow the project's coding standards.

step.name: Commit and Push
step.text: Commit your changes with a clear message and push the branch to your fork on GitHub.

step.name: Open a Pull Request
step.text: Go to the original repository and open a pull request. Provide a clear description of the changes you've made and reference the issue you are solving.
